content.description:
Follow a staircased ledge, angling left. Proceed up the face and out the roofs above. 

  Good route but Posey's Pass just to the left is more entertaining.
content.protection: Standard rack and slings - route moves laterally quite a bit
content.location: 10 feet right of Posey's Pass on the Overlook Wall - the bluff to the climber's left of the Island

content.description: Climb a large, left-facing flake to a small overhang. After the overhang, step left and up to a nice rest before the "inspiring" exit through a large slot in the final roof.
content.protection: Standard rack. You will need some long slings to reach natural anchors for toproping. Topropers also might want to place some redirects in the middle as well, or risk swinging out and being "whipped and beaten" by the big tree!
content.location: Starts on a face that lies to the right of the arete  on Classic Wall.

content.description: Start just a bit right of Snakebit.  Climb up through slightly overhanging ground.  Getting established under the roof was the crux for me.  Thin holds here lead to a surprising pocket and slopey holds to pull the roof.  Cruise to the top after that.
content.protection: Hard to setup TR without long slings.  Almost seems that most people use the Snakebit tree anchor with a directional over the arete.
content.location: Directly right of Snakebit and Cashmere.

content.description: Step off the ledge you are on and trend right under a small blocky roof section. Once under these small roofs trend right till you see a water run. Pull up over into the water run and go straight up to the top.
content.protection: Standard Rack. No anchors but great boulder (3ft diameter) and trees up top. Don't forget to pad the trees!
content.location: Starts 10ft from the off-width Chimney (5.6)   Starts 3 ft from the face climb Bubba (5.5)

content.description: Good route.  Scamper up some easy ledges to a crack pinched in by small roof.  Throw some pro in crack and power up crack..this is the crux.  Once over, have about 15' of easy slab with a crack to place pro.  Arrive at roof with little alcove to rest and place pro.  Throw in some big pro and pull roof. Not to hard to set up TR but need some webbing.
content.protection: Small cams low, bigger up high for roof. This climb now has bolts & rings at the top, to the right of the crack.
content.location: Route is on Cathedral wall, about 50 yards to the right of Cashmere.

content.description: Climb up to an obvious undercling, snag it and step up to pull the small overhang.Then pull the second roof to the top.
content.protection: Top-Rope. Trees at the top.
content.location: Never Never Land. The far end of the cliff line.

content.description: Climb the face just left of the arete. Reachy moves to crimps and horizontals take you past a few small overhangs to the top.
content.protection: Double up on finger sized stuff. Start more or less in front of the tree and you'll find gear down low. There's protection about every 5 feet or so for the entire climb if you have the wherewithal to hang out and place it. Bolted anchors at the top.
content.location: To the left of the arete to the left of the leaning Pillar. A little way right from Boobs.

content.description: Climb past the small right-facing flake right of Jumpin' Jeff Flash.
content.protection: Trad route, no top anchors, trees in the area up top.
content.location: Corridor Wall   Start 12' right of Jumpin' Jeff Flash

content.description: Climb into the slot, then over the "stumbling block" via cracks on either side. Continue up an easier crack system to the precarious-looking flat rock at the top.
content.protection: standard rack, hands to fingers
content.location: On the Redneck Wall just right of Steeples. Starts below a rectangular slot capped by a block.

content.description: thin corner crack system to the left of the route Jumping Jack Flash (crummy 5.8).  Start under roof of the block and work left into corner and layback up till route eases.  Follow crack straight up through roof system.  At roof, have a hard mantle to top out on sloping dirt finish...real easy to pitch off trying to flounder over top.  Easy to bail to Jumping Jack Flash to your right.
content.protection: takes ample pro entire route.  Hard to set up a TR.
content.location: In Corridor Wall.  Where trail goes up between a pinnacle of rock and the main wall in the corner system.

content.description: A steep, blocky start leads to more civilized climbing along a finger crack, which finishes at the ledge below the right side of the roof. Exit right around the roof, past the precarious-looking flat rock.
content.protection: standard rack, bolted anchors at top
content.location: On the Redneck Wall, on your way from the Island toward Boobs. Look for a ledge with a roof above it at the top of the wall. On the right side of the roof, there is a flat boulder wedged at an angle. The climb starts under the right end of the roof.

content.description: Climb the off-width crack in The Dark Side Wall left of Lady Fingers and Face Of The Phantom.
content.protection: Trad route, no top anchors, trees in the area up top.

content.description: Moderate face climbing leads to small roof moves.  Good TR to setup at the same time as Cashmere, if you have a few folks with you.  Leading any of these routes (NOTCL, Date with Death, etc..) in this area seems somewhat serious because of run-out and the potential fall from any of the roofs.  Crux is just somewhere on the face, depending on height.
content.protection: Small to medium gear.  Slings and gear for TR.
content.location: This route is located to the right of Cashmere.  It's directly right of Night of The Climbing Dead.  It's left of the Unnamed Arete(5.10) and left of Pickin' Pockets.

content.description: Fun face climbing leads to a steeper section beneath a small roof with a crack. Pull the roof and head for the top.
content.protection: standard rack
content.location: This route is on the Firetower Wall, to the left of the Elephant Crack roof.

content.description: Great route, very physical working up through the "inverted staircase." Crux is working out from under the "inverted staircase" through a roof split by a crack.  After pull through that, arrive at a nice stance then easy 5.6 climbing to top out.  This is one of the longer routes at Palisades.
content.protection: Med cams in the "inverted staircase."  Can set up a TR if jump across to the Island.
content.location: In middle of the face of the Island.  Look for a huge roof and on the left end of the roof is the "inverted staircase." It is unmistakeable.

content.description: Diagonal up and left across the face to meet up with the right-facing corner. Follow the corner to the top. For bonus points, when the corner is about to angle off to the left, continue straight up over juggy overhangs. (It's still 5.6.)
content.protection: Standard rack for leading. The usual long slings are required for toproping.
content.location: On the left end of a small, low-lying ledge on the face to the climber's left of the descent gully on the left side of the Island.

content.description: Climb the pillar.
content.protection: light rack, trees available for toproping
content.location: Look for the obvious pillar that is leaning against the wall on the way to Boobs.

content.description: Most people step around the first roof, but its worthwhile.  The second roof is good and has a huge jug, making it easy.  The grade really comes in on the climbing after the second roof.  The crux for me was about 3/4 of the way up.  Not exciting for southern hardmen but a good lead for the more novice folks.  Watch out in the summer for insects/poison ivy on the first roof.
content.protection: Small to medium gear.  No fixed anchors.  Trees and other usable objects at top for anchor building.
content.location: Route is located directly right of Cashmere by about 50ft of less.  Right before Ethereal Cathedral.  Look for a somewhat dirty roof system at the bottom that leads to another small roof.

content.description: Start same as Lady Fingers in the fun broken crack system.  Pull up onto the ledge and take the right route.  Don't go out all the way to the big roof.  You will see some nice incut jugs marking the route.  One of the easier 5.9's at Palisades becasue of good rest positions.  Not sustained like Lady Fingers.
content.protection: Toprope is easy to setup using trees and rocks at top.  Gear is small to medium. Sparse pro. at best.
content.location: Route is located on Dark Wall.  This is near/below the Meditation Point.

content.description: Starts beneath a boulder jutting out near the top of the wall. Climb up to the boulder, passing horizontals and short cracks. Continue up the short face above the boulder to top out.
content.protection: standard rack; I found a red tricam to be particularly helpful.
content.location: On the left end of the Redneck Wall, below an obvious boulder jutting out from the ledge below the roof up high.

content.description:
The Nose starts about 5 feet right of Post Nasal Drip, and climbs the overhanging "Nose", then finishes up the large overhanging crack.  This route and Post Nasal Drip finish together.   

  Start directly underneath the "Nose", climbing a steep but easy and juggy detached block under the nose.  To save strength for the crux you can start a few feet to the left and climb up the little gully and come up the back side of the detached block.   

  Once on top of the block, get ready for the crux.  Stand all the way out on the tip of the block and transition to the "Nose".  Get both hands in the horizontal on the "Nose" and swing out over the overhang.  Get your feet up and throw for a blind 2-3 finger pocket up on the left side of the "Nose".  Once you have the finger pocket, it eases up some, but it is sustained and steep until you're over the chicken head feature.  From there, it's 5.6 to the top.
content.protection: Standard Alabama rack.  Small to medium cams and nuts.  No bolts or anchors.  No fixed gear.  Plenty of trees at the top for setting up a toprope anchor, but you have to jump the gap to the Island, which can be dicey.
content.location: On the very tip of the Island, right in the middle.  It is halfway between the two walk-down passages on either side of the Island.  Look for the overhanging "Nose", and the inverted staircase of Post Nasal Drip just to the left.

content.description: Climb a crack in a right-facing corner, past a roof, to the top.
content.protection: standard rack, bolted anchors at the top
content.location: A right-facing corner on the Classic Wall, to the left of Captain Crunch.

content.description: Nice yellow face. really nice face moves to a left arching overhang to the top.   Pumpy face, and overhanging section.
content.protection: T/R set-up
content.location: Nice yellow face just right of Cashmere

content.description: Easy climbing through three short roofs. Then, pull the last roof via underclings to the lip finish with stout crimps up the namesake featurless arete to the top.
content.protection: Top-rope.
content.location: Walk down middle decent trail and go left at the cliff line, past Christmas Crack and you will see a featureless arete up ahead. Its location is on "The Island".

content.description: Start climbing just right of Christmas Crack. Good holds on slightly overhanging rock take you up to a big horizontal -- enjoy it while it lasts. A couple of tenacious moves take you to the namesake pocket, then claw your way to the top.
content.protection: Didn't see many possibilities for gear on the top half of this one. Hope you don't die. Good tree at the top for toproping.
content.location: On the climber's left side of the Island, just right of Christmas Crack.

content.description: Climb the arete past horizontal breaks and positive holds to the top.
content.protection: standard rack
content.location: An arete to the left of the downclimb between Redneck Wall and Meditation Point. On the right end of an orange-colored face.

content.description: For full value, start underneath the roof. Lunge out to the edge of the roof, and mantle onto the face. Mellow face climbing leads up to a steeper section and another crux at the top.
content.protection: standard rack
content.location: Look for a low-lying roof to the left of Boobs. This route starts at the left end of that roof.

content.description:
Great moves and epic fun the whole way! 

  Clamber onto the ledge above the trail. Start up the face above to a toaster oven-sized block below the first overhang. Reach to the obvious jug above the overhang -- gear is available in a horizontal up and right from the jug. Work your way over the hang and into a nice rest in a shallow left-facing corner. Plug in some gear, then move up and right to a pedestal ledge and more pro. Continue working right and up till you're below the corner. Feeling the pump yet? Lunge up to the corner, and then finagle your way up the corner to glory. 

  To descend, a short walk-off climber's left will bring you to the descent gully on the left end of Meditation point.
content.protection:
standard rack, doubling up on .75 Camalots might make you happy

 Bolted anchors with quicklinks at the top.
content.location: Meditation Point. Locate the long plank forming a bench on the side of the trail, which marks the left end of Meditation Point. From here, walk climber's right around the bend, beneath a large roof. Toward the right end of the roof, a ledge system about 10 feet above the trail will appear. This ledge system is the start of the climb. A gently overhanging face leads up and right to a right-facing, right leaning corner near the top of the cliff.

content.description: Gain the large horizontals above the low roof (you may have to jump). Climb up and through the shallow and thin micro gulley to the bolted anchors at the top.
content.protection: I've only top roped it.
content.location: To the left of Boobs and to the right of Mickey's Mantle

content.description: Look for dime-sized crimpers on a relatively smooth face. At the crux, beware of the Devil's Pocket--a smooth inverted paramid about halfway up.  It's good for a foot and nothing more.
content.protection: Anchors at the top
content.location: On the left side of Redneck Wall, find a downclimb next to a boulder.  Lead This? starts 2 feet to the right of the boulder.

content.description: Nice climb that shares the same start as Pharaoh's Revenge.  This one is a little more sustained than most 5.9's at Palisades.  Took me a few tries on the top part.  Not exactly sure if the upper left flake is part of this route or not, but either variation is 5.9.
content.protection: Toprope can be setup easily with trees and rocks at top.  Small to medium gear for leading.
content.location: On the Dark Wall, right of Five Nine Arete.

content.description: Cruise up a broken crack system to the ledge at the top.  Search for a hold on the ceiling of the flaky roof, and then lean out and go for it.
content.protection: Anchors at the top.
content.location: On Redneck Wall, starts about 6 feet to the left of Steeples, and finishes over the roof.

content.description: Obvious left arching crack ( Hands ). Nice to train beg. trad.
content.protection: BD # 3 &4. Can be top-roped.   A couple of pads and spotter if you are giong to boulder.
content.location: Obvious trail leading down hill from the base of Elephant Crack. Big boulder on the right and the 45 degree slab on the left.

content.description: not hard climb.  takes pro well.  if there is a crux its down low.  the rest of climb is a 5.5 romp to top.
content.protection: takes pro well. no fixed anchors at all and hard to TR
content.location: the big right crack in corner of Corridor Wall.

content.description: Climb a left facing crack and do some nice face climbing to the top.
content.protection: Top Rope. Trees at the top.
content.location: At the far end of the cliff line. End Rock.

content.description: Crux is pulling onto top part from the horizontal ledge.  The climb is an excellent top rope for folks not yet ready to lead it.  One of my favorites because of the sustained top part.  Much easier than Lady Fingers at the same rating.
content.protection: Small to medium gear.  Make sure to build a great anchor before you launch onto the final top 1/3.  The sidepull is tough to get up and established and you have to be ready to finish after that.  If you do toprope please pad the tree or use the crack, it takes small cams/nuts.
content.location: This route is at the far end of the cliff band near the fire tower.   If you are at the base its directly right of Box Lunch.

content.description:
The Flake Face begins on thin and reachy face moves which become progressively tougher through the middle of the bulge. It ends with a nuanced and balanced mantle-ish move over the bulge. Once you gain the top of the bulge/shield and can move comfortably, the climb is essentially complete. 

  This route feels harder than 5.11 until you unlock its mystery crux in the center of the shield/bulge. Definitely demands some accuracy and a bit of crimp strength.
content.protection: Top Rope. The new Dixie Cragger suggests using the anchors at the top of Dirty Dancing but in practice I would suggest using the anchors for The Flake instead (there will be a bit of rope rub on the bulge if you peel off)
content.location: Start about 4 feet left of Dirty Dancing. You should not have to use any part of the original Flake route (i.e. left facing side-pulls)

content.description: meat of the climb is working from the left facing corner crack, up and over the left facing "flake." Once on top of the flake, have a balancy move and then its a run to the top.  Great route.  One of the must dos at Palisades
content.protection: Takes pro well and easy to set up a TR.  However, if come off around the flake without good pro placed, can easily smack into the ledges below.
content.location: Route is in middle of Overlook Wall.  From the climb down behind the Island and the west corridor between the main wall and Island, the route is about 15' from the end of the corridor.

content.description: Climb the arete to the top.
content.protection: Trad route, no top anchors, trees in the area up top.
content.location: The Dark Side Wall   The arete left of Lady Fingers.

content.description: Start about 30 feet left of "Elephant Crack" and face climb to a small ledge.  Head right towards the large roof but then traverse back left on the way up.  There's a nominal roof here to go over then pick your holds to the top.
content.protection: Small to mid cams/nuts.  Fixed anchors at the top.
content.location: In the Fire Tower Wall section about 30 feet left of "Elephant Crack" just outside the large roof.  Rap from fixed anchors or hike the descent.

content.description: Stand start. Climb through good holds down low and pull hard through overhanging buldge. Then some really nice face climbing to the top.
content.protection: Top rope. No anchors.
content.location: Meditation point. To the right of Pharaoh's Revenge.

content.description: This route has the same start as Cashmere, but traverses left instead of through the roof.  The crux is probably the first couple of moves on the traverse at the top.  It requires a relatively long reach for a foothold.
content.protection: The crack leading up to the roof and the horizontal crack on the traverse take small to medium cams.  #1 Camalot and below is what I remember placing.
content.location: Start at Cashmere.

content.description: Face climb into the shallow left facing corner, follow this up to roofs, moving up and left for the desperate, dirty top out.
content.protection: A single rack of cams through #2 Camalot plus stoppers will do it. Take some slings for the roofs.
content.location: 25' right of the major arete to the right of Cashmere.

content.description:
At 5.6 in the guide, Elephant Crack is probably the most sandbagged route at Palisades.  The gear placements on the face are small and not easy to find, and the roof traverse is strenuous with good potential for an unpleasant pendulum fall.  This is an excellent route, but not a good choice for novice leaders. 

  Starting on a slightly slabby face, climb to a corner under the roof.  Underclinging the roof, traverse right about 25' to an outside corner and escape up the rain gully to the top.
content.protection: Small gear (mainly nuts) for the face section; small to medium cams for the roof traverse.  Sling trees for anchors at the top.
content.location: In the Fire Tower Wall section, not far right of the descent gully.  Starts below an obvious large roof.

content.description: Lieback the obvious crack. Finish just right of the overhang.
content.protection: Top Rope. Trees at the top.
content.location: To the left of walkway thats between the Overlook Wall and The Island. Good novice route.

content.description: great route, one of the best at Palisades.  Crux is pulling through the 3rd small roof onto the face.  After that, some 5.10 face climbing to the top.  The initial roofs are small and not hard to pull.
content.protection: Dk how well it would protect, as I have only TRed it.  It seemed as if you could protect ok.  To set up TR, have to jump across Island.
content.location: 40' to the right of Christmas Crack on the Island.  Look for 3 small roofs beneath a corner arete.

content.description:
Great crack climb, that evolves into easy face climbing above the short crack.  

  Work into crack and throw a solid left handed jam in crack and use features in crack to work feet up to a smear...throw your right hand to a high crimp just outside of the crack on the right wall.   

  Try not to put a cam in your best jam spot. 

  According to Tindell, its "harder" if you stay in the crack, but I have never done it that way.
content.protection: Crack takes cams nicely (med cams at base of crack, smaller higher in crack) and plenty of placements on face above.  Can set up a TR on top rather easily (have to jump across to the Island)
content.location: Route is on Left/West face of the Island, about 10' from the arete and the corridor.

content.description: Though the "chimney" is off-width, the highly-featured corner in which it resides means that you won't really need any off-width technique to climb it. A pleasant, albeit short, climb.
content.protection: We toproped it, so I'm not 100% on the pro. The chimney itself would big (fist and up) gear. The faces in this area tend to be cut with horizontals, so you may get some tiny stuff in there. Natural anchors for toproping.
content.location: Walk up to a dirt-covered ledge in the corner between Cathedral Wall and Never Never Land.

content.description:
Easy climbing leads to a nice easy roof.  

  Climb the crack to the base of the roof above. Load up the horizontals with gear and long slings. Work those feet up as you hand-over-hand out the large horizontal flake. Once fully extended, have faith and reach around to huge, hidden jugs. Cut loose and pull up onto the easy face above the roof. Climb this to the top.
content.protection: Stoppers, cams to #2 or so...there's good gear all over this route.
content.location: Long broken crack to a roof in a highly impacted area. Maybe 200' right of the 'descent gully'. Just left of the awesome face climb "Night of the Climbing Dead".

content.description: Climb up to the right to a small roof, pull itvia small undercling and finish with hard face climbing.
content.protection: Top-Rope. Trees at the top.
content.location: Never Never Land. To the right of Tinkerbell.

content.description: Start atop a blocky terrace under a low roof. Pull this roof, and work the broken crack to the top.
content.protection: Standard trad rack. This climb now has bolted anchors at the top. (They aren't visible from the ground.)
content.location: On the Classic Wall, 25' right of '9 to 5' a significant right facing corner.

content.description: Climb over a buldge to a nice ledge, move to the left about 7 or 8 ft. and continue with some steep face climbing.
content.protection: Top-rope set-up. No anchors. Trees at the top. Remember to pad the trees.
content.location: Meditation Point. About 10 or so ft. right of Marginal Monster (M&M.

content.description:
Easy but fun, Buckets is a nice route for first-time trad leaders, or a toprope for new climbers.  It's also a good warmup for some of the harder routes at the crag. 

  The start on Buckets is the only section of any difficulty.  Climb the face with little pro to a ledge about 10' up.  From here, good holds and lots of placements for pro lead to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack -- small to medium gear.  Sling trees at the top for anchors.
content.location: Located in the Fire Tower Wall area, Buckets starts about 15' right of the Elephant Crack roof.  After topping out, rap from a tree or walk left to the descent gully.

content.description: Mellow face climbing, mostly on jugs. Brief. Starts in the same corner as Chimney, but then heads out almost immediately onto the right face and trends upward and slightly to the right.
content.protection: A light rack will do. Bolted anchors at the top.
content.location: Start in the same corner as Chimney.

content.description:
Another Palisades sandbag (rated 5.7 in the guide), Box Lunch is a fun challenge on lead. 

  Easy climbing on horizontals leads to a thin face about two-thirds of the way up.  A jagged vertical crack in the face is the crux; look for a great captured nut placement here.  A generous horizontal crack provides a good rest stop after the strenuous crux move, as well as a vital placement to protect the finish.  Move up on slopers to the top.
content.protection: Gear up to #2 Camalot; good nut placements at the crux.  Anchor to trees at the top.
content.location: Located in the Pillar Wall section, just right of the leaning pillar.

content.description: Face climb upwards on reachy horizontals until under the roof. Crux is pulling the roof, in the vicinity of the groove. From here, moderate climbing on jugs to the finger crack and face finish goes to the top. Bail right and surf the flake after the roof if squeamish.
content.protection: Lots of horizontals...Can be well protected with yellow TCU through #1 Camalot plus stoppers. Double up if needed.
content.location: Starts 50' left of the pillar below two large protrusions above - the "boobs".

content.description: Last route on End Rock. Climb through an overhanging face to a small roof, pull the roof and continue on to the top.
content.protection: Top rope. Trees at the top.
content.location: End Wall. Far end of the wall. Around the corner from Arachnophobia.

climbs.name: A Little Help From My Friends

content.description: Start at the bottom of the staircased ledges (same as Warp Factor), at the top of the staircased ledges angle right up and out right of the roof.
content.protection: Standard rack.  After you angle right the face gets a little thin and the zig zag that this route contains offers some lovely rope drag.  Consider not protecting the far left of the ledges to minimize the drag.
content.location: Same start as Warp Factor at the bottom of the staircased ledges.  Located at Overlook Wall.

content.description:
If you're looking for a pleasant spot to bring friends new to climbing, Alabama's Palisades Park is a great choice. 

  Located not far from Birmingham, Palisades is a Blount County Park with a nice little cliff line running just below its parking lot. There's a good range of climbing difficulty, ranging from easy 5.4 up to roofy 5.12. Almost all routes can be easily top-roped without leading, and most have permanent anchors, so it's a perfect place for a beginner's first outdoor climbing experience. And if you're just getting started on trad, Palisades is an excellent training ground; routes like Buckets (5.5) offer easy leading and plentiful protection.  Be aware, though, that the grades tend to be sandbagged; Elephant Crack (5.6) and Box Lunch (5.7) are not for the novice leader. There's no sport climbing at Palisades; no bolting is allowed. 

  All climbers must register at the park office and buy a $5 climbing permit (good for three days) or a $35 annual permit. From the parking lot, head for the cliff top near a picnic pavilion and scramble down a fourth-class gully/chimney to the base of the cliff. 

  If you need a map of the routes, the park office will supply you with one.  Otherwise, the Dixie Cragger's Atlas is a good resource for routes at Palisades.
